page.title: 04ENVIRONMENT
page.content: SYCAMORE INVADES ANY UNUSED CORNER, WITH THE LOCAL RED-BERRIED ELDER EQUALLY QUICK TO COLONIZE. SPRING COMES LATE WITH HAWTHORN AND LARCH COMING INTO LEAF IN LATE APRIL AND THE FINAL ASH LEAVES ONLY AT MIDSUMMER. CURLEW AND OYSTERCATCHERS APPEAR EARLY IN THE YEAR AND HERONS CONGREGATE FOR COURTSHIP IN THE WET FIELDS NEAR THE TWEED IN FEBRUARY BEFORE THEY NEST IN A QUIET WOODLAND SITE. DIPPERS AND GREY WAGTAILS ARE COMMON IN THE BURNS WHILST IN WINTER MALLARD, GOOSANDER, PINTAIL DUCK AND TEAL CAN BE SEEN IN THE AREA. DESPITE PERSISTENT POISONING BY KEEPERS, KESTRELS, SPARROW HAWKS, HEN HARRIERS AND BUZZARDS ARE STILL IN EVIDENCE. THE SMALL BIRD POPULATION IS DOMINATED BY CHAFFINCHES AND TITS WITH ROBINS AND SONG THRUSHES ONLY POORLY REPRESENTED.
